captions.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

CHRIS HARRIS: Clever people
keep telling me that

everything will be
electric soon.

This fills me with the fear of
God, because I don't much like
electric cars.

But there's now a race among
some makers to prove that
electric can be exciting.

And the first to land is the
Mercedes SLS Electric Drive.

But is it a genuine alternative
to a supercar?

The SLS Electric Drive is a
strange mix of the familiar
and unfamiliar.

I know it's a bit odd to say I'm
familiar with the interior

of the SLS, but I did
run one for a while.

And it's quite conventional
Mercedes in its layout.

But of course, being electric,
it just has a couple of

slightly strange things that
look profoundly different to
the normal production car.

To start with, we have this rev
counter here that shows

percentage of energy
being used.

It has a battery temperature
gauge, and it has a battery
life gauge.

The center screen is a computer
readout that tells

me, again, how much battery life
I've got, because that

seems to be the pertinent
thing.

The central screen here, well
they've taken the and now

turned it into something that
looks like a computer game.
It's absolutely fantastic.
You'll see that now.

It tells you what's going on
and where torque is going.

The rest of the controls
are quite conventional.
Got a normal steering wheel.

My paddles, they now control
the amount of brake
regeneration I've got.

So I can either have a lot of
brake regeneration, which

gives massive retardation when
you let off the pedal, and a

lot of regenerative power going
back into the batteries.

But it does mean that if there
was a car following me on the

road, they'd probably
rear end me.

Gear lever is the same
as the normal SLS.

You pull it back into drive,
there's a bit of a whirring as

the handbrake goes off, and
now in complete silence.

And honestly, at the moment, the
loudest thing is the fan
that's on two at the moment.
We just roll away.

And we do so in one of the three
driving modes, this one
called comfort.
Comfort is as described.

It gives us the easiest,
most relaxed throttle
position in the car.

So we've got quite a long
throttle as we push on now,
doing 25, 30 miles an hour.
Just remarkable.

Less spring rate than I think
in a standard SLS.

The car's heavy, obviously,
nearly 2.2 tons, with a bit
more with two people on board.

I've got nice steering weight,
not too light.
Circuit's very slippery today.
Performance--

well, at the moment I've got
around 440 kilowatts.

I probably better do the math
on that for you in a minute.

But it does mean that if I thump
my foot down, it doesn't

feel as quick as
a standard SLS.
It doesn't.
But even so, this is--

in this form, in its most
sanitized form-- the SLS

Electric Drive still feels like
a proper performance car.

It's still got good amounts
of performance.
Look at that.
Foot down, 60, 70, 80--
that's quite quick.
Ceramic brakes work well.

The torque vectoring that's
going on here is massively
complicated.
It's unbelievable.

We've got four electric motors,
one at each corner,

and all of the torque would be
monitored the whole time

according to your steering
angle, lord knows what else.

As a calibration exercise,
this is unprecedented.
So let's go into sport mode.

So now I've got a slightly
more responsive throttle.

And I've got a chassis which is
trying to make things a bit
sharper for me.
The car feels--

yeah, certainly feels a
bit more responsive.
This is just freakish.

This whole torque vectoring
thing is freakish.

I think torque vectoring might
almost be more interesting

than the fact that this car
is electrically driven.

It's the new snake oil of
chassis design, isn't it?

I mean, it almost gives
infinitesimal possibilities,

the fact that you
can put negative
torque into one wheel.

So the wheel that's moving the
slowest in the corner, if you

want, you can drag that
wheel back to nothing.
That's incredible.

You can make the
car just turn.

And this car does feel very
agile for something so heavy.

In comfort and sport, the car
is limited to 200 kilometers

per hour, so 125 miles
an hour in old money.

That's about fast enough,
isn't it?

And if you drive the car like
this, ie not too harshly, you
could probably cover about--
I don't know, 160, 170 miles.
If you gun it, well, yeah.

It becomes a bit more
inefficient then.

Interestingly, I tried to push
Mercedes on some real CO2

figures, because
they claim that
the car is zero emissions.
Well it's not, is it?

It pushes the emissions
to another point
in the carbon cycle.

If a normal SLS is 300 and
something grams per kilometer,
then this--

realistically in a northern
European nation that uses a

mixture of nuclear, coal, and
increasingly, some renewable
energy sources--

this is around 15 to 20
grams per kilometer.

So it's still pretty
efficient.
Wow.

This is quite alarmingly quick,
even in sport mode.
Now, sport plus.
Sport plus.

I've got a much more responsive
throttle now.

And I now have 740 something
horsepower, 1,000 newton

meters of torque,
737 foot pounds.

And I'm limited to 150
miles an hour.
That won't be a problem here.

But this is a slippery track,
so I've got to be
a little bit careful.
What happens?

Well, the torque vectoring is
doing an incredible job of
keeping me on the circuit.
It's very slippery today.

And what it's doing is allowing
each wheel to do its

maximum given the
circumstances.

But rather than getting really
juddery brakes, it actually

feels like the tire has reached
its limits of grip and
just stops there.

Just keep your foot planted, and
it's seamless and smooth.

And then when it lets go in a
straight line, I mean, it's
quick, isn't it?

Neil's speechless next
to me, recording.
This is new.
This is profoundly new.
It's genuinely fast, guys.
It's genuinely fast.

I'm not sure what this means
for the future of the

motorcar, because this is
400,000 pounds by the time
you've paid a few taxes.

There's no right-hand
drive version.

And it's a technology that's
available now, but it's also
massively complex.

It's not ultimately as usable
or as flexible as
a combustion engine.

And it's not a car for
the people, is it?
Although this is modular.

So imagine 740 something
horsepower.

Well, you could take a third
of this and stick it in an
A-class, and you're away.

Not as much fun as
that though.

I mean, that is just back to the
future when you squirt it
down the straight, isn't it?
Blimey O'Reilly.
Torque vectoring--
very, very interesting.

Now, there are three
modes here, and we
can play with them.

So we have the ability to switch
off torque dynamics
into sport now.

So this allows me, again, to
have a completely different
chassis setup on the car.
So this is less cautious.
It will allow a bit of slip.
Look at that, a bit of slip.

Now, this is all done
through electronics.

It's slippery as hell, and
it's just managing
everything for me.

And it's all done on
steering angle.

What's really freakish about the
dynamics of this car with

the torque vectoring is that in
a conventional sports car,

you have the same ultimate
behavior of the car, and you

just play with the levels
of intervention.

Yeah, you can put more support
into the car by stiffening the
dampening up.

And you can play with other bits
and bobs, and some cars

have differentials that will
change a bit as well.

But ultimately, the character
of the car is the same.

You just play with the
intervention levels.

With this car, when you go from
comfort to sport plus,

you have a totally
different car.
It feels quite different.
It performs differently.

The axles behave differently
according to the grip levels

and the amount of power
being thrown at them.
Bizarre.

So sport mode gives us
a bit more slip.
Mega.
Absolutely mega.

The vaguely oversteering
electric car.
Tell you what, though.

We could try the completely
oversteering electric car.
[CAR SKIDS]
[INTERMITTENT BUZZING]

CHRIS HARRIS: That's an electric
car in a skid.
[LOUD BUZZING]

CHRIS HARRIS: About five minutes
ago, I was out of the

track, which is wet,
oversteering a four wheel
drive electric car.
I've never done that before.

So rather than stand around that
car and try and have my

mind blown, we've come inside
to this cutaway.

And I want some of this
technology explained to me--

how this works, why it works,
and how they've reached this

level of performance from the
car, because I just wasn't
expecting it.
OK.

First of all, four electric
motors, yeah?

JAN FEUSTEL: Four electric
motors, one in each wheel.

CHRIS HARRIS: Torque split,
25% per corner?

JAN FEUSTEL: That's the
basic setup, yes.

CHRIS HARRIS: But
it can change?

JAN FEUSTEL: And it will change
if you're driving in a
dynamic way.

Torque vectoring will help you
set the right torque on the

right wheel in the
right second.

CHRIS HARRIS: So we have the
battery packs mainly in the

center of the vehicle within the
carbon structure, which is

completely different
to an SLS.

So even though the car looks
like an SLS on the outside,

underneath, it's nothing to do
with an SLS at all, is it?
It's completely different.

JAN FEUSTEL: It's completely
different.

We changed the body in white in
terms of the center of the

vehicle, the spine
of the vehicle.

We do have a zero intrusion cell
made out of carbon fiber,

which is pretty much the
backbone of the vehicle, gives

the body in white a lot
of the stiffness
that you already felt.
And it's additional--

it's an intelligent way of our
strategy of lightweight

performance, since that battery
housing is part of the
body in white.
CHRIS HARRIS: OK.

Actually in twist, is this
stiffer than a normal SLS?

JAN FEUSTEL: Yes it is, due to
the carbon fiber housing.

CHRIS HARRIS: That's
interesting.

But we have a lot of
mass down here.

We have 550 kilograms or so,
don't we, of batteries?
JAN FEUSTEL: Yes.

CHRIS HARRIS: But the actual
center of gravity is quite

good, because it's low and in
the middle of the car, yes?
JAN FEUSTEL: Yes.

And the center of gravity in
total, in the center of

gravity of the vehicle, is about
an inch lower than in
the regular SLS.

CHRIS HARRIS: The electric
motors-- how much power do we

have coming from the front and
the rear axle in terms of
electric motor power?
What's the split?

JAN FEUSTEL: Each electric motor
provides 138 kilowatts,
so they all four are the same.
Basic setup is 25% each.

So the total is 552 kilowatts,
which is 750 horsepower.
And the--
CHRIS HARRIS: Sorry.

How do you say that
without smiling?

You've made an electric
car 750 horsepower.
JAN FEUSTEL: 750--

CHRIS HARRIS: That is
utterly bat [BLEEP]
isn't it?

Think about it, 750 horsepower
and 1,000
newton meters of torque.
Carry on.
Sorry.

Just try not to smile when
you say it, all right?

JAN FEUSTEL: With 750
horsepower, it's the most
powerful electrical car.

And it's the most powerful
AMG ever.

CHRIS HARRIS: Let's have a
little look around a couple of
bits and bobs.
Talk me through the cells.

The cells come from
South Korea?
JAN FEUSTEL: Yes.
CHRIS HARRIS: How many cells?
JAN FEUSTEL: 864.

CHRIS HARRIS: OK, in all, and
they come in blocks of--
is it three big blocks?

JAN FEUSTEL: Actually,
what we see here is
what we call one module.

And we do have 12 equal modules
in the vehicle.

Four of these modules are
mounted together to a battery.

So from an electric point of
view, we do have three equal
batteries in the car.

CHRIS HARRIS: And I suppose
from an R&D perspective--

because this is an R&D project,
and we have to
remember that--

it's entirely possible
to take one of those.

You could take one of those
and put them in a car.
JAN FEUSTEL: You can.

You won't have that much
fun, but you can.

CHRIS HARRIS: But you still
have a third of 750
horsepower, don't you?
JAN FEUSTEL: Yes.

CHRIS HARRIS: That's
quite a lot--

JAN FEUSTEL: Yeah, that's
quite good.

CHRIS HARRIS: --by conventional
standards.
How long do these last for?

If you recycle them properly,
if you charge them and

discharge them properly, how
long does that last for?

JAN FEUSTEL: During development,
we did a lot of

testing in terms of cycling,
of aging, corrosion tests.

And we kind of torture our
components to make sure they
will last in customers' hands.

But that battery is made
to last for 10 years.
CHRIS HARRIS: 10 years.

So we're not worried
about that.
In terms of range--

so if I drive the car normally,
I don't try and

drive too fast, I keep the car
in comfort mode, maybe for 20%

of the time of a full charge, I
have it in sport plus and I
go a bit quicker.

How many kilometers
do you think?

JAN FEUSTEL: The certified
range is 250 kilometers.

But as you said, the real life
range that you can achieve in

an everyday use might
be around 200.

This is what we expect, even
though if you know how to

drive the vehicle in an economic
way, you will be able
to reach 250.

But if you're cruising in, let's
say, more or less normal

traffic, 200 is a realistic
answer.

CHRIS HARRIS: 225 miles, which
is still a long way, given

that I'm not used to electric
cars having any range
whatsoever.

Just talk me through the
way that each gear box
works on each axle.
Can we have a look at that?
JAN FEUSTEL: Sure.

CHRIS HARRIS: I presume-- and
you'll tell me I'm wrong now.
And we're on video.
He's recording--

do we just have a reduction
gear effectively here?
Is that what we're doing?

We're just taking a motor and
reducing its speed down?

JAN FEUSTEL: Basically,
that's what we do.

We have one, two electric motors
are facing each other.

They're mounted onto
one gear box.

And inside this gear box,
actually, there's two

independent gear
sets in there.

So the right motor doesn't know
what the left one does.
They're facing to each other.
There's two sets of gears.

And there's a driveshaft
connected to the axles.

So differential is realized
in an electronic way.

And that's why torque vectoring
can tell that motor

independently from this
one what we want
to do with the vehicle.

And that is the key for the fast
reaction and the ability

to control the vehicle
in a dynamic way.

CHRIS HARRIS: Talk me through,
effectively, negative torque,

the way that you can apply what
you call negative torque
to a wheel in a situation.
How does that work?

JAN FEUSTEL: Negative torque
is a thing that you--

you might have difficulties to
understand what negative
torque means.

For instance, if you go through
a corner on your

right, these two wheels on the
left hand side, they get all

the vehicle load, so you can
put the maximum positive
torque onto these two wheels.

If you're turning into the
corner, the two left wheels,
they get this negative torque.

And it's not that we're turning
wheels backwards.

It's more like breaking down the
wheel, or kind of try to
turn it backwards.

If you rip it off and turn
it backwards, then
you lose the grip.
That's not what you want.

So you kind of break it down
and turn it backwards.

And by moving this way, these
two have maximum torque

positive and these
two negative.
This is--

you can imagine, it turns
automatically
without steering angle.

CHRIS HARRIS: You're
not actually
running the motor backwards.

You're just pulling the
torque back to zero.
JAN FEUSTEL: Exactly, yes.

CHRIS HARRIS: And that's what
you call negative torque?

JAN FEUSTEL: Well, we don't
turn it back to zero.

We are even able to
turn it backwards.

CHRIS HARRIS: So it's actually
decelerating the wheel?
JAN FEUSTEL: Yes.

CHRIS HARRIS: And this is all
done through the gear box and

the motor, nothing to
do with the brake?

You're not using the brake
disc at all to trim it?

JAN FEUSTEL: Torque vectoring
doesn't work with brakes,

since brakes kind of-- it takes
some time to activate

them and to get the
pressure there.

The electric motors, they set
it right as you want it.
CHRIS HARRIS: Madness.
Absolute madness.

OK, I think that's about
all the tech we can
digest in that period.

But that is a car that requires
a lot of thinking

once you've driven it, and I
need to go and think now about
what I've experienced.

I don't think it's an immediate
solution for the

super sports car, because
obviously it's expensive, and

it doesn't quite have the range,
and it's heavy, and it
has some downsides.

But if you told me two or three
years ago that there

would be an SLS for sale that
was completely electric that

could perform like this,
I just wouldn't
have believed you.

The SLS Electric Drive is too
limited and too heavy to be a

genuine replacement
to a supercar.

But it's much, much
more exciting
than I'd ever expected.

This is a showcase for
what's coming.

And it's mostly good news,
even if it looks like the

smaller, lighter batteries we
really need are still at least
a decade away.
It's a totally bizarre car.

I feel like Marty McFly
the moment he got
into the bloody DeLorean.

If you made a time machine
out of an SLS--
it's absolutely bizarre.

title: Mercedes SLS Electric Drive. Can Volts Ever Match Pistons? - /CHRIS HARRIS ON CARS
